author: sky.cactus
content: Sorry for the lack of clarity.  I think integration testing is valuable, but I don't think there is a whole lot of value in running those early integration testnets for extended periods of time.  I believe most integration testing bugs showed up basically as soon as a new client tried to connect, not after it was running for 2 weeks?

author: sky.cactus
content: Basically, I think there are incredibly steep diminishing returns on integration testnets, where you get almost all of the value up front.  Sometime before launch we *should* do a long term integration testnet, but Ropsten, Rinkeby, Kovan, etc. are better for that IMO.

author: sky.cactus
content: And maybe one integration testnet that is explicitly designed to exercise some edge cases (doesn't need to run for a long time, but it does need to hit a bunch of edges).

author: sky.cactus
content: For test scenarios, I think it would be interesting/useful to see what happens when individual actors have a fee threshold, and when the base fee is higher than that they leave and come back to try again after some period of time (e.g., an hour, a day, a week).
